{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3726018,"name":"Roger","username":"Takumi1203","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/takumi1203/{size}/262151_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-29T23:51:03.951Z","cooked":"

IMG_49101920×2560 583 KB

Hey guys, just wanted to know for the PDH(Power Distribution Hub). Is it true that the ports closer to the battery port has the better performance. Some says you should wire your drivetrain motors to the ports closer to battery port. Personally speaking, I think the advantage is too slight to make the drive base go faster. Instead, you have to put the wire over each other(because you can’t connect the wire to the port that is closest to you), and it doesn’t look clean and it will lose some maintainability.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-08-30T17:36:29.516Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":431,"readers_count":430,"score":181.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505772,"topic_slug":"cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution","display_username":"Roger","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74861,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3256 electrical"},"post_url":"/t/cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution/505772/1","custom_user_title":"3256 electrical","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3726027,"name":"Saber_8871","username":"tyron256","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/tyron256/{size}/177261_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-30T00:05:36.900Z","cooked":"

Im going to preface this by saying i havent tested anything personally but conventional logic regarding resistance increasing with the length of medium to cross (in this case the rails within the PDH responsible for distributing power) says that the theory behind what youre saying could be true.

That being said, i think the differences are going to be minimal if not non existent given that the power would be routing through extended wires as opposed to the PDH rails. You would get more noticeable returns from making sure wires are kept as short as they can be within reason to reduce length of travel.

Once again, i could be wrong especially if accounting for draw from other subsystems

","post_number":2,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-08-30T00:05:36.900Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":1,"reads":421,"readers_count":420,"score":254.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505772,"topic_slug":"cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution","display_username":"Saber_8871","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":11}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":7167,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":""},"post_url":"/t/cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution/505772/2","custom_user_title":null,"reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":9},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":11,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3726028,"name":"Rich Jr","username":"rich.varone","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/rich.varone/{size}/167373_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-30T00:07:05.053Z","cooked":"

I believe that technically yes the ports closer to the battery port have better performance, BUT is it going to make any difference for the 99.9% of teams, probably not, aka no it’s not gonna turn your Ls into Ws, you’re way better off focusing on the maintainability of cleaner management in this case.

","post_number":3,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-08-30T01:37:11.538Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":410,"readers_count":409,"score":172.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505772,"topic_slug":"cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution","display_username":"Rich Jr","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":6998,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271"},"post_url":"/t/cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution/505772/3","custom_user_title":"FRC 271 | Lead Mentor | Fabworks Discount Code: FRC271","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3726235,"name":"","username":"Robotgobrrrr","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robotgobrrrr/{size}/238076_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-30T05:14:29.297Z","cooked":"

What’s likely to be a bigger difference maker is from the picture it looks like you’re using aluminum wire for the motors. Aluminum has a higher resistivity which will translate to more of your battery energy being dissipated as heat through the wires.

The game manual even specifies to use copper wire under R622.

Your original idea is pretty interesting though, it makes sense it really just comes down to how significant of a difference there is between the close and far side. I might break out the multimeter tomorrow and collect some measurements.

Thank you for pointing out R622! And please share the data you collect!

","post_number":5,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-08-30T05:35:36.501Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":4,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":310,"readers_count":309,"score":97.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":505772,"topic_slug":"cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution","display_username":"Roger","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":57453,"username":"Robotgobrrrr","name":"","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/robotgobrrrr/{size}/238076_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74861,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3256 electrical"},"post_url":"/t/cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution/505772/5","custom_user_title":"3256 electrical","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3726276,"name":"Mark Wasserman","username":"Mark_Wasserman","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/mark_wasserman/{size}/9677_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-30T13:43:11.424Z","cooked":"

There is a difference between near and far slots.

CTR Electronics 2024-25 | New Products General Forum
Stryke Force had the opportunity to beta test the performance of a CTR PDP 2.0 and compare it to a REV PDH. With higher power motors, peak currents as high as 400 Amps are possible. This might not be an issue for some teams; however, we routinely see these high peaks during match play and with concerns of a potential brownout, an analysis of where the voltage is going seemed warranted. The method of testing was to draw 50 Amps from varied outputs and precisely measure the voltage drop across …

I will admit it hurts my brain to cross wires just to get to a stiffer port on the PDH/PDP but we would do it for the reason of squeezing out every mV.

","post_number":6,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-08-30T13:43:11.424Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":256,"readers_count":255,"score":121.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505772,"topic_slug":"cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution","display_username":"Mark Wasserman","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"link_counts":[{"url":"https://www.chiefdelphi.com/t/ctr-electronics-2024-25-new-products/473711/240","internal":true,"reflection":false,"title":"CTR Electronics 2024-25 | New Products","clicks":0}],"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":4}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":30473,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly"},"post_url":"/t/cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution/505772/6","custom_user_title":"Not fast swerve, but good swerve driven quickly","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":4}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":4,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3726280,"name":"Sam","username":"Sam948","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/sam948/{size}/261363_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-30T13:58:35.704Z","cooked":"

I can also tell you that using long battery wires can lead to brownouts (don’t ask how I learned that)

","post_number":7,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-08-30T13:58:35.704Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":238,"readers_count":237,"score":77.6,"yours":false,"topic_id":505772,"topic_slug":"cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution","display_username":"Sam","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":2}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":63767,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"8847A | PV"},"post_url":"/t/cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution/505772/7","custom_user_title":"8847A | PV","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":2}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":2,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3726282,"name":"Richard Wallace","username":"Richard_Wallace","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/richard_wallace/{size}/110760_2.png","created_at":"2025-08-30T14:05:54.476Z","cooked":"

Qualitative thinking is generally the place to begin, but those who aim for solutions to real problems must eventually think quantitatively.

As an initial thought exercise, consider that 10 AWG wire has a resistance of one milliOhm per foot. With 100A flowing in it, the voltage drop will be 100 millivolt per foot. If you want less drop, make the wire either shorter or fatter or both.

Mark’s team, and every team trying to eke out just a wee bit of competitive advantage, helps that cause by fighting for millivolts.

","post_number":8,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-08-30T14:05:54.476Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":232,"readers_count":231,"score":166.4,"yours":false,"topic_id":505772,"topic_slug":"cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution","display_username":"Richard Wallace","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":6}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":1549,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"I live for the details."},"post_url":"/t/cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution/505772/8","custom_user_title":"I live for the details.","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":6}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":6,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3729105,"name":"Eric Bergquist","username":"kitare102","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-02T15:28:18.442Z","cooked":"

It’s a good point to make sure your wire is copper and not aluminum. However, it’s more likely that this wire is tinned copper, which has been plated with a very thin layer of tin to prevent oxidation and improve solderability. You should be able to tell by looking at the cut end of one of the strands. If the center is orange-ish, it’s tinned copper. May need a magnifying glass, since the high-strand wire you have there has very fine strands that may be hard to see.

","post_number":9,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-09-02T15:28:18.442Z","reply_count":2,"reply_to_post_number":5,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":176,"readers_count":175,"score":180.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505772,"topic_slug":"cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution","display_username":"Eric Bergquist","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":74861,"username":"Takumi1203","name":"Roger","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/takumi1203/{size}/262151_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":7}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":23148,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Coach Eric, FRC 3100 Mentor"},"post_url":"/t/cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution/505772/9","custom_user_title":"Coach Eric, FRC 3100 Mentor","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5},{"id":"100","type":"emoji","count":1},{"id":"point_up","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":7,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3729134,"name":"Roger","username":"Takumi1203","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/takumi1203/{size}/262151_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-02T15:48:19.175Z","cooked":"

Yes! Our teammate told me it is the tinned copper! Your view of point is correct!

","post_number":10,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-09-02T15:48:19.175Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":166,"readers_count":165,"score":78.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505772,"topic_slug":"cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution","display_username":"Roger","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"reply_to_user":{"id":23148,"username":"kitare102","name":"Eric Bergquist","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":74861,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"3256 electrical"},"post_url":"/t/cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution/505772/10","custom_user_title":"3256 electrical","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3729167,"name":"Chris Herzog","username":"zog","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/zog/{size}/266762_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-02T16:27:41.354Z","cooked":"
kitare102:

It’s a good point to make sure your wire is copper and not aluminum. However, it’s more likely that this wire is tinned copper, which has been plated with a very thin layer of tin to prevent oxidation and improve solderability.

You’re spot on here for cases where the wire has a silver color.

Aluminum wire is often copper plated - or CCA (Copper Coated Aluminum). In that case it’s the opposite of @kitare102 mentioned - it’s copper on the outside and silver on the inside.

This is vile stuff and should be avoided (it also runs afoul of R622).

Check wire descriptions carefully - there is a lot of CCA wire out there because aluminum is cheaper than copper. If you’re buying from a reputable vendor, descriptions will be accurate. If you’re buying from Amazon vendor superdupergoodwires that you’ve never head of and is really cheap - well….

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":14,"updated_at":"2025-09-02T16:51:39.112Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":9,"quote_count":1,"incoming_link_count":0,"reads":156,"readers_count":155,"score":136.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":505772,"topic_slug":"cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution","display_username":"Chris Herzog","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":2,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":null,"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":5}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":40142,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]"},"post_url":"/t/cleaner-or-slight-better-performance-drivetrain-position-on-power-distribution/505772/11","custom_user_title":"Doin' robot stuff... [ FRC 2151 + 3061 | Ri3D Redux '23 | RIP 4292 & 4241 ]","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":5}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":5,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3729632,"name":"Anand Rajamani","username":"asid61","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/asid61/{size}/7179_2.png","created_at":"2025-09-03T00:36:44.318Z","cooked":"

Were you able to get test data that can delineate between the root, trunk, and branch resistances? The data you posted before resolved to around 0.1 milliohm per port of trunk resistance, which is similar to an inch of 12awg wire (or half an inch round trip). Of course, you’d be running multiple wires as opposed to having the draw come through the PDH, but it does seem pretty close unless you draw a huge amount of current somewhere above the drivetrain.

It seems to me that in a lot of difference between the ports will be obviated by the fact that by using the “near slots” will make it so the wires are longer compared to using the closest slot to the motors. 6” of 10 awg wire has 0.2 V of drop at 400A, which is most of the difference between near and far in the numbers you provide for the PDH. 1’ (6” red, 6” black) of 10 awg wire has 0.4 of drop at 400A which is more than the difference between near and far slots for the PDH. If crossing the wires makes the wires even longer, that will further eat into performance.

So to the OP, I’d use the slots best for organization/minimizing wire length.
